Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), where A and B are constant matrices. We study the impact of the transformation defined by \\( h(z) = e^{Ct}z \\) over time t, where C is another constant matrix.

If \\( h(z) \\) is applied to a complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( h(z) \\) modifies the initial state by scaling and rotating the components depending on the structure of C. This transformation substantially alters how \\( z(t) \\) evolves, leading to a different state at time T due to the individual effects of A and B on x and y components.
